headline.main: The pot lobby; Perhaps the most improbable lobbying effort in Washington is the serious attempt to reform the nation's marijuana laws. The pot lobby All about pot

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. The capital's most improbable lobbyist, 29-year-old Keith Stroup, was sitting at his cluttered desk beneath his "Reefer Madness" wall poster, sipping a Pepsi and recounting with his usual enthusiasm how he came to start NORML, the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Law:

headline.main: Asbestos, the saver of lives, has a deadly side; Asbestos The skin of the salamander Picture Credits

docs.abstract: R Sherrill article on link between mesothelioma, asbestos-caused cancer of chest or abdominal lining, and shipyard work performed during World War II
docs.lead_paragraph: Shipyard work attracted about 4.5-million Americans into its ranks at one time or another during World War II, and an estimated 3.25-million of those people are still alive. If they think about the experience at all these days it is probably to again remind themselves with satisfaction that things could have been worse.
